Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D4G5-00000-00FB Led Technically as Mark Zuckerberg Testified Before Congress; WSJ: U.S. Points Finger at Chinese Firms for Transhipping; White House Weighs Actions in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack; Nunes Prepared To Impeach Head of FBI and Deputy Attorney General2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:06ZLexisNexisFB Led Technically as Mark Zuckerberg Testified Before Congress; WSJ: U.S. Points Finger at Chinese Firms for Transhipping; White House Weighs Actions in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack; Nunes Prepared To Impeach Head of FBI and Deputy Attorney GeneralLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, I'll see you both shortly. Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th. Your top stories at 6a.m. Eastern.

Stocks surging, the Dow climbing more than 400 points yesterday after China's President Xi Jinping promised an open market and to cut tariffs on auto imports. Futures are showing this, 400 plus point gain on the Dow Futures on the Dow yesterday. Ninety point loss on the Dow Futures today.

In Europe, stocks there mostly lower. Across the board losses in England, France, and Germany, although slight. And it was mixed reaction in Asia overnight with gains in Shanghai and on the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

One of the top winners yesterday, Facebook shares seeing their biggest gain in two years, up about four and a half percent as CEO Mark Zuckerberg did an admirable job facing a grilling on Capitol Hill from people who clearly didn't understand Facebook, some of them. He was grilled on everything, from the Cambridge Analytica scandal, Russian election interference, you name it, he was asked it, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility and that was a big mistake and it was my mistake and I'm sorry. I started Facebook, I run it, and I'm responsible for what happens here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: What Mark Zuckerberg's testimony could mean for future regulation in the tech sector, that's ahead. He's back on Capitol Hill at 10:00a.m. this morning.

Nunes fighting back, the Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee set to go after Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and FBI Director Christopher Wray as the Justice Department still refuses to provide him with an unredacted document showing the justification for their Russia probe. The latest on the tensions in the Capitol, that's ahead.

Bank of America changing its stance on firearms. The bank says it will no longer lend money to companies that make so-called assault rifles for civilians.

Plus, never give up on your dreams, after spending 10 years in the development league, on basketball player delivers a slam dunk in his long- awaited NBA debut. The incredible story coming up.

And one small step for man, one giant leap online, NASA helping you channel your inner Neil Armstrong with a brand new virtual tour of the moon.

All of that coming up and so much more this morning, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. FOX Business's Connell McShane. And Kairos Founder, Ankur Jain. Ankur, just really quickly, what was your take on Zuckerberg yesterday?

ANKUR JAIN, FOUNDER, KAIROS: I'm going to tell you, Mark did a great job. I mean, all things considered.

MCDOWELL: I love how you refer to him by his first name.

JAIN: But I mean look, I got to tell you, the good thing was I think that Zuckerberg did a great job for Facebook. I think the challenge that the congressmen had no idea what to ask to actually address the problem, and that's a challenge. This is an important topic. And if you're going to have the Senate sitting there taking the time to figure out what regulations technology need, they need to know the right questions asked.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN ANCHOR: Yes, right. We have another episode of old people talking technology at 10:00 this morning, right? They had no idea how to follow-up was the main point.

JAIN: I mean, honestly some of other was just a lack of understanding what Facebook is. Somebody -- I forget which one of the congressman held up a poster board of five Facebook groups and goes, "Mr. Zuckerberg, are you -- can you authenticate that these were not owned by Russian trolls?"

If I were him, I would have been like, "There are three billion groups. I don't remember every single group." I mean, it's just --

MCSHANE: Right.

JAIN: It's just a shame.

MCDOWELL: He was prepped. He bought the kind of legal prep that billions of dollars can buy, put it that way. And he followed the script that was handed to him, we'll get into that. That's what we're talking about, the top of the show.

And coming up this morning, Texas Congressman, House Financial Services Committee Chairman, Jeb Hensarling. Texas Congressman Ted Poe. Former Presidential Candidate Herman Cain. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Dr. Mike, Dr. Mikhail Varshavski on the snake diet, yes, that's one of our things that we'll be discussing with Dr. Mike.

But to our top story this hour, Mark Zuckerberg squaring off with lawmakers on Capitol Hill, the Facebook CEO testifying for about five hours before skeptical senators who demanded answers on how the social media company allowed Cambridge Analytica to misuse the personal data up to 87 million Facebook users.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DUBIN (D), ILLINIOS, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE MEMBERS: Mr. Zuckerberg, would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?

ZUCKERBERG: No.

DUBIN: If you've messaged anybody this week, would you share with us the names of the people you've messaged?

ZUCKERBERG: Senator no, I would probably not choose to do that publicly here.

DUBIN: I think that might be what this is all about. Your right to privacy, the limits of your right to privacy, (INAUDIBLE) in modern America, "connecting people around the world."

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R), LOUISIANA, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE MEMBER: Here's what everybody's been trying to tell you today and I say this gently, your user agreement sucks. You can spot me 75 IQ points, if I can figure that, you can figure that. The purpose of that user agreement is to cover Facebook's rear-end, it's not to inform your users about their rights.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Investors did react positively to Zuckerberg's performance. Shares of the social media company were up four and a half percent. Mark Zuckerberg returns to Capitol Hill this morning. He is set to testify before House lawmakers.

Joining us now, Gabelli Multimedia Trust Portfolio Manager, Larry Haverty. Larry, my takeaway if -- looking at it from a market perspective and in an investor perspective is, even without additional regulations which might be coming, Facebook's going to be spending a lot more money on security, on policing the content on that social media platform. Is that fully factored into the stock, their increase in expenses?

LARRY HAVERTY, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, GABELLI MULTIMEDIA TRUST: Well I think that's the $64,000 question here. There are two context that I think this discussion needs to be framed in.

The first is the emotional context and that was the theater that the Congressional grilling provided for viewers yesterday. Five hours is an awfully long time and I think Mark did very, very well on that. I'd give him an A- grade. I thought the best answer was the hotel one and I think - - I thought he gave the wrong answer when I heard it but then I thought maybe it was the right answer because he does need to maintain his personal security and frankly, it isn't anyone's real business where he stays.

The second question remains answer -- unanswered though and that's the financial question. And you look at what Facebook's doing, they've said they're going to add 5,000 people, that's a good crowd for a small college basketball game. Those people are going to need facilities, I think that's at least a $1 billion cost, that raises the cost based on Facebook by a very significant amount.

Now, this is a company with very, very strong margins. My guess is that the margins are going to go down at least 500 points but I think we have to wait two weeks to more or less figure this out when Facebook reports its first quarter and I'm pretty sure if the people gave Zuckerberg the advice they did and he performed as well as he did, the crisis managers are going to tell them how to handle the earnings release which I think is to be upfront with the cost on this as much as possible and I think that's not a hundred percent, they're not going to know until probably a year later how much they spent.

They'll clearly be a significant one-time charge but with $41 billion, that's not a big deal. Net-net, the stock had been in my opinion, if nothing went wrong and clearly that's no longer the case. The stock had been priced very cheaply relative to its growth and I think it can handle this once the computers that are trained especially in technology investments to detest the margin contraction get few -- get through with selling the stock the minute the numbers come out because I think there will be margin pressure greater than people expect and I think once the numbers come out, the first trade will be down on the stock in a couple weeks. So --

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, what was your take yesterday on what happened?

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Well I think the stock was up because this could have been just a relief rally or maybe it was a short selling -- a short squeeze, excuse me.

Larry, I'd love to get your take though, when I think about Facebook, I wonder about the future of this company because you have Mark Zuckerberg out there talking to the press saying and -- to senators saying that, "Look, we are kind of like a media company, you are seeing expense going up, you're going to see margin compression." Trading at 22 times, yes, that's a huge discount to its historical average but it's still premium to media companies. Where is this company going to evolve to? You've got Sheryl and Mark talking about paid subscription services, what is the future of Facebook and what's the right valuation to value that?

HAVERTY: Oh, I think the secret sauce here is very important and that's the first thing I learned about this company and mercifully I learned it before it went public from talking with some people who did business with the company.

The advertising works and it's very unique. You have David Ogilvy, one of the advertising gurus historically 50 percent of advertising works, I just don't know which 50 percent. Facebook can prove its efficacy, it's more efficient than alternatives. So advertisers, unless there are real, real major problems are going to embrace it. They're not going to walk away. A few may walk away, my guess is maybe you lose two to three percent on add volume, you're clearly going to have cautious CPM pricing for the next 12 months and then I think the systems will write themselves but this company has a tremendous comparative advantage versus comp.

MCDOWELL: CPM being called for million (INAUDIBLE)

HAVERTY: Tremendous.

MCDOWELL: Cost for thousand views (INAUDIBLE)

HAVERTY: Yes, cost for thousand.

MCDOWELL: I want to get your take on what you heard about regulation from these senators yesterday because it's not going to be just Facebook. As an entrepreneur, are you worried about Washington getting in the way of innovation and creation?

JAIN: So I think -- look, let's break it out. One, Zuck said himself that Facebook is open to the right kind of regulation. I think secondly, it's really not the Facebook problem, right? I mean, Google has as much or more data on users than Facebook does.

The question is, what's the right kind of regulation? After watching the Congress yesterday ask their questions, I worry that if they're left to create regulation it will do things that stifle innovation and actually block the services that actual people --

MCSHANE: We never got to that question about what the -- I mean, maybe we did. I mean, to the entire -- to whatever else, five or six hours but what I saw, it never got to your question which is what is the right type of regulation.

I think Kamala Harris, the senator from California maybe came closest and she tried to press him, I think it was in the 6:00 hour Eastern Time talking about Cambridge Analytica data breach. It's like, why didn't you tell the users about that? He's like, "We know that they are taking our data, we know they're using it for advertising to make it more targeted." But once there's a breach, why weren't the users told about that and what type of regulation can help prevent that in the future? And he dodged.

JAIN: I think the common theme you saw throughout Zuck's testimony was transparency.

MCSHANE: Right.

JAIN: And I think that is ultimately where the right regulation goes, is that as long as these companies are transparent about what they're doing with data, what's happening with the data, I think at that point, the user's decisions on how much they want to give Facebook, how much they want to use Facebook, et cetera. And so, hopefully the Congress will lean towards that kind of regulation.

MCDOWELL: But I will end on this note, one, Sheryl Sandberg needs the same kind of grilling from the legal team that Mark Zuckerberg does because, again, her kind of like flip hair-toss reaction to what's been going on at Facebook for the last decade is a little dismissive to investors and two, what was ironic was listening to those senators asks Mark Zuckerberg those questions was the equivalent of watching my 82-year-old father try to use Facebook.

MCSHANE: That's right.

MCDOWELL: That he was like -- it was the equivalent of like flicking the phone like there's a bug on it and then dimming the screen to the point that he throws the phone at you and tells you he -- that Facebook broke his phone, that's what it felt like.

JAIN: If Facebook does have access to people's car records, I'd love for them to release how many Congressmen called their grandkids that morning and say, "Can you please quickly walk me through Facebook before I interview this Mark guy."

MCSHANE: Yes. It's embarrassing. A bunch of times it's embarrassing. It was -- I mean, it's almost like when we do an interview with someone, you - - a lot of times you know the subject, you're ready to follow-up like this. But if you're not -- if you don't know the topic, you can ask the first question, forget about the follow-ups and that was -- what happened a ton yesterday.

MCDOWELL: But fear the wiley southerner because I think Lindsey Graham acted all folksy and very foghorn leghorn but then he backed Mark into trying to basically asking him if you have a monopoly. And so I thought that he used -- he was like, "Go ahead, assume that I'm stupid because I'm from the south" and then he went in for the kill shot.

JAIN: It was definitely smart at some point.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you Ankur. Larry, it was great to have you here, terrific analysis as always, please come back very, very soon Larry Haverty.

HAVERTY: Thanks a lot.

MCDOWELL: And keep it here on FOX Business for live coverage of Mark Zuckerberg's testimony before House lawmakers today, starts at 10:00a.m. Eastern Time.

Meantime, Bank of America's big move against guns, the bank won't lend to companies that make so-called assault weapons for civilian use. The controversy coming up.

And time is up, House Intel share Devin Nunes is done waiting for the FBI and DOJ to hand over Russia probe documents. And now he says it's time for someone at the top to face serious consequences. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Sprint and T-Mobile talking about a merger again. Cheryl Casone has the detail, Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: Yes, really Dagen. The third fourth largest U.S. wireless carriers are back in the negotiating table again. The merger would lump together 127 million customers and get some serious competition to Verizon and AT&T, that nation's top two providers.

T-mobile and Sprint were in talks before but those ended because the (INAUDIBLE) valuation disagreements between the two companies. Since then, Sprint stock has taken a dive, it lost about a fifth of its value. The company has long-term debt of more than $32 billion. Shares of T-mobile are also down nearly six percent year-to-date. So, we shall see.

Theranos is making some major job cuts, report say the blood testing firm laying off almost everybody that works there in an effort to keep the company afloat and avoid bankruptcy. The layoffs chopped the company's workforce from 125 to about two dozen employees, that is way down from 2015, they had 800 people there at the time. Founder and CEO Elizabeth Homes has announced the staffing changes nearly a month after settling civil fraud charges with the SEC which forced her to give a voting control over her own company and pay a $500,000 fine.

Well, WalletHub has released its annual list of best places to live for millennials. Here are the top three states, Minnesota ranked high on the list coming in at number three. North Dakota coming in at number two, these are very cool places. And then get this, the top spot not technically a state but it's the nation's capital. According to the study, Washington, D.C. the best place for millennials to live.

Millennials make up 35 percent of D.C.'s workforce, key indicators of living standards like average monthly earnings for millennials and, of course, the unemployment rate for them were looked at. D.C. millennials say that the abundance of people their age is also a big attraction for moving there. MCDOWELL: You run a bad candidate who runs a bad campaign like what happened in Pennsylvania and the Democrats win.

CAIN: That's a different story.

MCSHANE: Do you think Paul Ryan being out energizes the -- if this is true, would energize Republican basis?

(CROSSTALK)

CAIN: I don't think -- it would energize the members that are pretty sure they're coming back but not necessarily the voters. The voters have got to be energized with a very strong, very clear Republican message, which they don't have out there right now. The results are on their side with this President. But they have not taken it and crystallized their message.

MCDOWELL: I agree, all over the place, what we say down south. Switching gears. The FTC says it's OK to remove those pesky warranty stickers. Lauren Simonetti has more.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN REPORTER: Hey there. The Federal Trade Commission says these warranty void if removed sticker are B.S. They fired off a letter to six manufacturers -- you've seen those -- of cars, phones and video game consoles. This is what they wrote, "provisions that tie warrantee coverage to the use of particular products or services harm both consumers, who pay more for them, as well as the small businesses who offer competing products. We don't know which companies were warned but think -- Sony think Microsoft as they make many of the products in question."

The FTC says they're breaking the law because a manufacturer can't tell a consumer they can't fix their own stuff or that they can't have a third party fix it. So here's an example. You buy a new Honda. It breaks. You take it to your local mechanic. They can't fix it and you take it back to Honda. The FTC says Honda cannot deny you return because you went to the repair shop first. That thinks to the 1975 (INAUDIBLE) consumers don't know about this. We don't know our rights and many companies exploit that with those no trespassing stamps that we just showed you. So bottom line, do your homework. You can take your stuff back. This applies to Apple iPhones, by the way, if the screen is messed up. Usually a third party is allowed to fix it.

MCSHANE: You just sounded like Lindsey Graham at the hearing yesterday with the whole car example for a second. Which is actually a good example yesterday.

MCDOWELL: Lindsey Graham was pulling -- you know, he was doing that whole southern trick. I'm going to sound stupid but I'm going to catch you, right?

CAIN: It might not be a trick with him. I'm just saying. Wow. I'm just saying it might not be.

MCSHANE: Coming in heavy.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Somebody on Twitter just called you gentleman. Now not so much.

CAIN: Oh, wow. I don't do political correctness. You know that.

MCDOWELL: I love having Herman Cain here. And the message from Lauren as those companies can stick those stickers where the sun don't shine.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: You're welcome.

MCDOWELL: Coming up. A major test for Mark Zuckerberg. How the Facebook CEO responded to lawmakers grilling him about his company's data scandal, next. Plus Jim Carrey slamming the President again, the backlash over his latest insulting tweet ahead.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Markets are under pressure, we just got the numbers for last month's CPI, the consumer price index hitting the tape. You haven't seen much movement in the Dow Futures right here, right now. The month-over-month top line CPI was down one-tenth of a percent, that was a drop that was unexpected. But if you look at the year-over-year number which is critical, a 2.4 percent gain on the overall number, core CPI excluding food and energy was up 2.1 percent, which is still a pretty hot inflation number considering what we've seen in the last 10 years.

And then we have rising tensions with Syria also weighing on investors in these Markets. Futures extending their slide after President Trump tweeted this earlier: "Russia vows to shoot down any and all missiles fired at Syria. Get ready, Russia, because they will be coming, nice and new and smart. You shouldn't be partners with a gas-killing animal who kills his own people and enjoys it."

Checking the global market action, in Europe, we have losses across the board. More than a one percent loss on the DAX in Germany. And in Asia overnight, those markets already closed for the day, we had some mixed markets.

Facebook not the only tech giant under fire. New questions over Amazon and its tax practices. We take a closer look ahead. And Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, the CEO, facing questions over bias against conservatives. We have viral stars Diamond and Silk reacting to the hearing later this hour.

And then there's deadline day, the FBI and Justice Department have until today to turn over the unredacted memo that led to the Russia investigation. The initial two-page electronic memo, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes threatening legal action if law enforcement does not comply. And is this the end? Is it coming for Robert Mueller? The White House weighing in on the special counsel and his future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I know a number of individuals in the legal community and including at the Department of Justice that he has the power to do so. We've been advised that the President certainly has the power to make that decision.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We're looking at the fallout from those comments. And then Jim Carrey, the so-called artist, taking aim at President Trump and Putin with his latest piece of artwork. The backlash ahead. And investors tuning into Spotify in its first week of trading. Now, the company is looking to keep up the success. The big plans for your listening habits. But first, are special counsel Robert Mueller's days numbered? Blake Burman joins us from the White House with a lot more. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Dagen, good morning to you. After President Trump openly mused here at the White House on Monday that some people, he says, are telling him that he should fire Robert Mueller. The White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said yesterday that they do believe the President have that power.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: I know a number of individuals in the legal community and including at the Department of Justice that he has the power to do so, but I don't have any further announcements on --

REPORTER: But it is -- they told me (INAUDIBLE) they said it's Rod Rosenstein who oversees the special counsel, only he has the power to fire the special counsel.

SANDER: Again, we've been advised that the President certainly has the power to make that decision. I can't go anything beyond that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Democrats and even several Republicans on Capitol Hill though are calling for the special counsel to be protected. While the top Republican on the House Intelligence Committee has his sights set elsewhere. Congressman Devin Nunes saying last night that if he does not get an unredacted version of the document that he says started the Russia investigation, then he wants the head of the FBI and the number two at the DOJ to lose their jobs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R), CALIFORNIA, CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I'll just tell you that we're not going to just hold in contempt. We will have a plan to hold in contempt and to impeach.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: To impeach Christopher Wray?

NUNES: Absolutely.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Rod Rosenstein?

NUNES: We're not -- we're not messing around here.

BURMAN: In a tweet earlier this morning, President Trump said that there was, "no collusion or obstruction other than I fight back. President Trump had described that earlier this week as a, quote, attack on our country. In a harsh rebuke yesterday on the Senate floor, Chuck Schumer described that assertion as a, quote, disgrace. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Blake Burman, thank you for the reporting, as always. Blake, at the White House for us. Now, on the Capitol Hill, Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg set to be grilled by House lawmakers today. This, after testifying for roughly five hours before some skeptical Senators who demanded answers about how the social media company allowed Cambridge Analytica to misuse the personal data of up to 87 million Facebook users.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DURBIN (D), ILLINOIS: Mr. Zuckerberg, would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?

ZUCKERBERG: No.

(LAUGHTER)

ZUCKERBERG: Senator, no, I would probably not choose to do that publicly here.

DURBIN: I think that may be what this is all about, your right to privacy, the limits of your right to privacy, and how much you give away in modern America in the name of, quote, connecting people around the world.

KENNEDY: Here's what everybody's been trying to tell you today. And I say this gently. Your user agreement sucks. You spot me 75 I.Q. points. If I can figure it out, you can figure it out. The purpose of the user agreement is to cover Facebook's rear end, it's not to inform your users about their rights.

MCDOWELL: Joining me now is Professor of Marketing at NYU Stern School of Business, author of "The Four: The Hidden DNA of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google," Scott Galloway. Scott, your take on Zuckerberg's performance yesterday?

SCOTT GALLOWAY, PROFESSOR OF MARKETING, NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: It was remarkable on how unremarkable it was. He's -- you know, he's the winner here because the bottomline is he didn't screw up. There was a couple of good sound bites there. But it's nothing -- there was no real moment. And D.C. is the big looser. You think 55 adults would have gotten in a room and said we can't really do anything in four or five minutes each. Who knows technology, raise your hand? Three or four people would have raised their hand out of the 55. And they said, why don't we give each of you more than five minutes so you can actually drill down. It was the format that made this literally a useless exercise.

MCSHANE: That's a really good point.

CAIN: And I agree with you, 200 percent. Absolutely. It was remarkably unremarkable. Most of them knew that going in but it was the opportunity to get five minutes on T.V. That's all it was about. And nothing's going to come out of this, other than Zuckerberg is going to say, well, I'm highly concerned about this whole, you know, screening out conservative stuff. We will take that under advisement.

BELL: Yes, exactly. I think that's a great point, Herman. Scott, what does Mark do after two days of testimony in front of Congress?

GALLOWAY: He goes back to work and he does nothing, and he hires more lobbyists, there's a lot of job (INAUDIBLE) for lobbyists, for Facebook. The bigger -- the folks that are about to go gangster on Facebook right now are in Europe, specifically (INAUDIBLE). Europe in the last week has made more progress if you will or proposed more legislation against Facebook than America has to date. France is talking about taxing them on their top line because Google figured out a way to do $7 billion in revenue in the U.K. and paid $50,000 in taxes. They're talking about regulating Facebook and Twitter as media companies and Britain. Their GDRP is well ahead of anything we're doing. This is a nothing burger here in D.C.

MCSHANE: See, he was told specifically -- his notes, they didn't really leak, they were -- pictures were taken of his notes as they were left out on t he --

MCDOWELL: The A.P. -- right, A.P. took -- the A.P. photographer got a shot of the notes, the prep work that his lawyers had done for him.

MCSHANE: And to Scott's point, he was talking exactly what you were saying, he was instructed if that came up to not really say anything about it, to not come out and say -- which is interesting, well, what would your take would be on this, he was told apparently according to those notes, don't say we're already doing what they're regulating in Europe, that we're already doing that. Apparently, it said that in his notes that he wasn't supposed to come out and say that.

GALLOWAY: Well, there's been a lot of serious lies in big tech. Information wants to be free, that was a lie. We not only comply with the tax laws, we comply with the spirit of the tax laws. That was Tim Cook. The spirit of U.S. tax laws isn't that you issue your I.P. to the isle of man so you can suppress taxes in the U.S., high-tax domain, and increase them in low-tax domains. That's not the spirit of the U.S. tax law. The most recent big lie from big tech was Mark Zuckerberg saying, I'm not sure we shouldn't be regulated. I'd really like to know if the lobbyists in D.C. representing Facebook are running around saying, you know what, we're open to regulation. That is so ridiculous. CAIN: The only thing that Mark Zuckerberg said that I agree with, if Congress passes regulations, as you know they're going to be too big and too many and it's going to keep any challengers out of the marketplace because a new start-up is going to have a tough time dealing with it. I agree with you. Leave them alone. Let the customers of Facebook decide Facebook's future.

MCDOWELL: It was pretty clear based on the questioning that the last tech gadget some of these senators had bought was a Playskool View-Master, that they don't -- they have no concept of how even cell phones work quick frankly. You brought up taxes. I want to bring up this issue with you, Scott. 15 U.S. corporations including Amazon found ways to avoid taxes on nearly $25 billion in combined profits last year. This is a report from the institute on taxes and economic policy. Amazon received $137 million rebate on $5.4 billion in profits resulting in an effective tax rate of a negative 2-1/2 percent. And Trump -- of course, President Trump's been attacking Amazon for not paying enough in taxes. But again, this kind of goes to your point.

GALLOWAY: We've institutionalized a regressive corporate tax structure. Since 2008, Wal-Mart has paid $64 billion in corporate income tax, Amazon has paid 1.4 billion. This is despite the fact that Amazon has added a value of Wal-Mart to its Market cap in the last three months.

So what we've effectively we -- our tax system around big tech is sort of the Hunger Games. If you survive it and you win, you live a fabulous life and you can avoid taxes. The tax system is so complex and so favors large multinationals that it's basically a transfer of wealth from small domestic and medium-sized companies that only have domestic operations to large multinationals who can afford large tax departments and then can do these sort of -- these unnatural gymnastics to figure out a way to suppress their taxes in high-tax domains. We have -- Amazon is about to view us -- Amazon is about to become the most valuable company in history, and effectively pay no tax.

So, the question becomes when the most successful company in the world doesn't pay taxes, who does pay taxes? And it's simple, less successful companies pay taxes. You know, Alexa, is this a good thing?

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. I want to ask you, though, about with Facebook and its future. GALLOWAY: Well, going back to Herman's comments, I don't think the revolution is going to be consumer-led. I don't think this is going to be consumer-led. And when 280 million Americans, 213 million of them are on Facebook, you don't really have any choice. In addition, when you have 5 million advertisers and no one advertiser can really hurt you, you're a monopsony. Advertisers have no choice but to be on Facebook. So, bottom line, this is a monopoly. I think the answer is to break these guys up, Facebook, Instagram, messenger, WhatsApp, healthier for the economy.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You can take your mic off. Drop it. Great for you. That was a drop-the-mic moment. Scott Galloway, thank you so much.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D4G3-00000-00FB Led Technically as Mark Zuckerberg Testified Before Congress; WSJ: U.S. Points Finger at Chinese Firms for Transhipping; White House Weighs Actions in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack; Nunes Prepared To Impeach Head of FBI and Deputy Attorney General2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:06ZLexisNexisFB Led Technically as Mark Zuckerberg Testified Before Congress; WSJ: U.S. Points Finger at Chinese Firms for Transhipping; White House Weighs Actions in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack; Nunes Prepared To Impeach Head of FBI and Deputy Attorney GeneralLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, I'll see you both shortly. Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th. Your top stories at 6a.m. Eastern.

Stocks surging, the Dow climbing more than 400 points yesterday after China's President Xi Jinping promised an open market and to cut tariffs on auto imports. Futures are showing this, 400 plus point gain on the Dow Futures on the Dow yesterday. Ninety point loss on the Dow Futures today.

In Europe, stocks there mostly lower. Across the board losses in England, France, and Germany, although slight. And it was mixed reaction in Asia overnight with gains in Shanghai and on the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

One of the top winners yesterday, Facebook shares seeing their biggest gain in two years, up about four and a half percent as CEO Mark Zuckerberg did an admirable job facing a grilling on Capitol Hill from people who clearly didn't understand Facebook, some of them. He was grilled on everything, from the Cambridge Analytica scandal, Russian election interference, you name it, he was asked it, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility and that was a big mistake and it was my mistake and I'm sorry. I started Facebook, I run it, and I'm responsible for what happens here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: What Mark Zuckerberg's testimony could mean for future regulation in the tech sector, that's ahead. He's back on Capitol Hill at 10:00a.m. this morning.

Nunes fighting back, the Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee set to go after Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and FBI Director Christopher Wray as the Justice Department still refuses to provide him with an unredacted document showing the justification for their Russia probe. The latest on the tensions in the Capitol, that's ahead.

Bank of America changing its stance on firearms. The bank says it will no longer lend money to companies that make so-called assault rifles for civilians.

Plus, never give up on your dreams, after spending 10 years in the development league, on basketball player delivers a slam dunk in his long- awaited NBA debut. The incredible story coming up.

And one small step for man, one giant leap online, NASA helping you channel your inner Neil Armstrong with a brand new virtual tour of the moon.

All of that coming up and so much more this morning, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. FOX Business's Connell McShane. And Kairos Founder, Ankur Jain. Ankur, just really quickly, what was your take on Zuckerberg yesterday?

ANKUR JAIN, FOUNDER, KAIROS: I'm going to tell you, Mark did a great job. I mean, all things considered.

MCDOWELL: I love how you refer to him by his first name.

JAIN: But I mean look, I got to tell you, the good thing was I think that Zuckerberg did a great job for Facebook. I think the challenge that the congressmen had no idea what to ask to actually address the problem, and that's a challenge. This is an important topic. And if you're going to have the Senate sitting there taking the time to figure out what regulations technology need, they need to know the right questions asked.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN ANCHOR: Yes, right. We have another episode of old people talking technology at 10:00 this morning, right? They had no idea how to follow-up was the main point.

JAIN: I mean, honestly some of other was just a lack of understanding what Facebook is. Somebody -- I forget which one of the congressman held up a poster board of five Facebook groups and goes, "Mr. Zuckerberg, are you -- can you authenticate that these were not owned by Russian trolls?"

If I were him, I would have been like, "There are three billion groups. I don't remember every single group." I mean, it's just --

MCSHANE: Right.

JAIN: It's just a shame.

MCDOWELL: He was prepped. He bought the kind of legal prep that billions of dollars can buy, put it that way. And he followed the script that was handed to him, we'll get into that. That's what we're talking about, the top of the show.

And coming up this morning, Texas Congressman, House Financial Services Committee Chairman, Jeb Hensarling. Texas Congressman Ted Poe. Former Presidential Candidate Herman Cain. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Dr. Mike, Dr. Mikhail Varshavski on the snake diet, yes, that's one of our things that we'll be discussing with Dr. Mike.

But to our top story this hour, Mark Zuckerberg squaring off with lawmakers on Capitol Hill, the Facebook CEO testifying for about five hours before skeptical senators who demanded answers on how the social media company allowed Cambridge Analytica to misuse the personal data up to 87 million Facebook users.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DUBIN (D), ILLINIOS, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE MEMBERS: Mr. Zuckerberg, would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?

ZUCKERBERG: No.

DUBIN: If you've messaged anybody this week, would you share with us the names of the people you've messaged?

ZUCKERBERG: Senator no, I would probably not choose to do that publicly here.

DUBIN: I think that might be what this is all about. Your right to privacy, the limits of your right to privacy, (INAUDIBLE) in modern America, "connecting people around the world."

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R), LOUISIANA, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE MEMBER: Here's what everybody's been trying to tell you today and I say this gently, your user agreement sucks. You can spot me 75 IQ points, if I can figure that, you can figure that. The purpose of that user agreement is to cover Facebook's rear-end, it's not to inform your users about their rights.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Investors did react positively to Zuckerberg's performance. Shares of the social media company were up four and a half percent. Mark Zuckerberg returns to Capitol Hill this morning. He is set to testify before House lawmakers.

Joining us now, Gabelli Multimedia Trust Portfolio Manager, Larry Haverty. Larry, my takeaway if -- looking at it from a market perspective and in an investor perspective is, even without additional regulations which might be coming, Facebook's going to be spending a lot more money on security, on policing the content on that social media platform. Is that fully factored into the stock, their increase in expenses?

LARRY HAVERTY, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, GABELLI MULTIMEDIA TRUST: Well I think that's the $64,000 question here. There are two context that I think this discussion needs to be framed in.

The first is the emotional context and that was the theater that the Congressional grilling provided for viewers yesterday. Five hours is an awfully long time and I think Mark did very, very well on that. I'd give him an A- grade. I thought the best answer was the hotel one and I think - - I thought he gave the wrong answer when I heard it but then I thought maybe it was the right answer because he does need to maintain his personal security and frankly, it isn't anyone's real business where he stays.

The second question remains answer -- unanswered though and that's the financial question. And you look at what Facebook's doing, they've said they're going to add 5,000 people, that's a good crowd for a small college basketball game. Those people are going to need facilities, I think that's at least a $1 billion cost, that raises the cost based on Facebook by a very significant amount.

Now, this is a company with very, very strong margins. My guess is that the margins are going to go down at least 500 points but I think we have to wait two weeks to more or less figure this out when Facebook reports its first quarter and I'm pretty sure if the people gave Zuckerberg the advice they did and he performed as well as he did, the crisis managers are going to tell them how to handle the earnings release which I think is to be upfront with the cost on this as much as possible and I think that's not a hundred percent, they're not going to know until probably a year later how much they spent.

They'll clearly be a significant one-time charge but with $41 billion, that's not a big deal. Net-net, the stock had been in my opinion, if nothing went wrong and clearly that's no longer the case. The stock had been priced very cheaply relative to its growth and I think it can handle this once the computers that are trained especially in technology investments to detest the margin contraction get few -- get through with selling the stock the minute the numbers come out because I think there will be margin pressure greater than people expect and I think once the numbers come out, the first trade will be down on the stock in a couple weeks. So --

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, what was your take yesterday on what happened?

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Well I think the stock was up because this could have been just a relief rally or maybe it was a short selling -- a short squeeze, excuse me.

Larry, I'd love to get your take though, when I think about Facebook, I wonder about the future of this company because you have Mark Zuckerberg out there talking to the press saying and -- to senators saying that, "Look, we are kind of like a media company, you are seeing expense going up, you're going to see margin compression." Trading at 22 times, yes, that's a huge discount to its historical average but it's still premium to media companies. Where is this company going to evolve to? You've got Sheryl and Mark talking about paid subscription services, what is the future of Facebook and what's the right valuation to value that?

HAVERTY: Oh, I think the secret sauce here is very important and that's the first thing I learned about this company and mercifully I learned it before it went public from talking with some people who did business with the company.

The advertising works and it's very unique. You have David Ogilvy, one of the advertising gurus historically 50 percent of advertising works, I just don't know which 50 percent. Facebook can prove its efficacy, it's more efficient than alternatives. So advertisers, unless there are real, real major problems are going to embrace it. They're not going to walk away. A few may walk away, my guess is maybe you lose two to three percent on add volume, you're clearly going to have cautious CPM pricing for the next 12 months and then I think the systems will write themselves but this company has a tremendous comparative advantage versus comp.

MCDOWELL: CPM being called for million (INAUDIBLE)

HAVERTY: Tremendous.

MCDOWELL: Cost for thousand views (INAUDIBLE)

HAVERTY: Yes, cost for thousand.

MCDOWELL: I want to get your take on what you heard about regulation from these senators yesterday because it's not going to be just Facebook. As an entrepreneur, are you worried about Washington getting in the way of innovation and creation?

JAIN: So I think -- look, let's break it out. One, Zuck said himself that Facebook is open to the right kind of regulation. I think secondly, it's really not the Facebook problem, right? I mean, Google has as much or more data on users than Facebook does.

The question is, what's the right kind of regulation? After watching the Congress yesterday ask their questions, I worry that if they're left to create regulation it will do things that stifle innovation and actually block the services that actual people --

MCSHANE: We never got to that question about what the -- I mean, maybe we did. I mean, to the entire -- to whatever else, five or six hours but what I saw, it never got to your question which is what is the right type of regulation.

I think Kamala Harris, the senator from California maybe came closest and she tried to press him, I think it was in the 6:00 hour Eastern Time talking about Cambridge Analytica data breach. It's like, why didn't you tell the users about that? He's like, "We know that they are taking our data, we know they're using it for advertising to make it more targeted." But once there's a breach, why weren't the users told about that and what type of regulation can help prevent that in the future? And he dodged.

JAIN: I think the common theme you saw throughout Zuck's testimony was transparency.

MCSHANE: Right.

JAIN: And I think that is ultimately where the right regulation goes, is that as long as these companies are transparent about what they're doing with data, what's happening with the data, I think at that point, the user's decisions on how much they want to give Facebook, how much they want to use Facebook, et cetera. And so, hopefully the Congress will lean towards that kind of regulation.

MCDOWELL: But I will end on this note, one, Sheryl Sandberg needs the same kind of grilling from the legal team that Mark Zuckerberg does because, again, her kind of like flip hair-toss reaction to what's been going on at Facebook for the last decade is a little dismissive to investors and two, what was ironic was listening to those senators asks Mark Zuckerberg those questions was the equivalent of watching my 82-year-old father try to use Facebook.

MCSHANE: That's right.

MCDOWELL: That he was like -- it was the equivalent of like flicking the phone like there's a bug on it and then dimming the screen to the point that he throws the phone at you and tells you he -- that Facebook broke his phone, that's what it felt like.

JAIN: If Facebook does have access to people's car records, I'd love for them to release how many Congressmen called their grandkids that morning and say, "Can you please quickly walk me through Facebook before I interview this Mark guy."

MCSHANE: Yes. It's embarrassing. A bunch of times it's embarrassing. It was -- I mean, it's almost like when we do an interview with someone, you - - a lot of times you know the subject, you're ready to follow-up like this. But if you're not -- if you don't know the topic, you can ask the first question, forget about the follow-ups and that was -- what happened a ton yesterday.

MCDOWELL: But fear the wiley southerner because I think Lindsey Graham acted all folksy and very foghorn leghorn but then he backed Mark into trying to basically asking him if you have a monopoly. And so I thought that he used -- he was like, "Go ahead, assume that I'm stupid because I'm from the south" and then he went in for the kill shot.

JAIN: It was definitely smart at some point.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you Ankur. Larry, it was great to have you here, terrific analysis as always, please come back very, very soon Larry Haverty.

HAVERTY: Thanks a lot.

MCDOWELL: And keep it here on FOX Business for live coverage of Mark Zuckerberg's testimony before House lawmakers today, starts at 10:00a.m. Eastern Time.

Meantime, Bank of America's big move against guns, the bank won't lend to companies that make so-called assault weapons for civilian use. The controversy coming up.

And time is up, House Intel share Devin Nunes is done waiting for the FBI and DOJ to hand over Russia probe documents. And now he says it's time for someone at the top to face serious consequences. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Sprint and T-Mobile talking about a merger again. Cheryl Casone has the detail, Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: Yes, really Dagen. The third fourth largest U.S. wireless carriers are back in the negotiating table again. The merger would lump together 127 million customers and get some serious competition to Verizon and AT&T, that nation's top two providers.

T-mobile and Sprint were in talks before but those ended because the (INAUDIBLE) valuation disagreements between the two companies. Since then, Sprint stock has taken a dive, it lost about a fifth of its value. The company has long-term debt of more than $32 billion. Shares of T-mobile are also down nearly six percent year-to-date. So, we shall see.

Theranos is making some major job cuts, report say the blood testing firm laying off almost everybody that works there in an effort to keep the company afloat and avoid bankruptcy. The layoffs chopped the company's workforce from 125 to about two dozen employees, that is way down from 2015, they had 800 people there at the time. Founder and CEO Elizabeth Homes has announced the staffing changes nearly a month after settling civil fraud charges with the SEC which forced her to give a voting control over her own company and pay a $500,000 fine.

Well, WalletHub has released its annual list of best places to live for millennials. Here are the top three states, Minnesota ranked high on the list coming in at number three. North Dakota coming in at number two, these are very cool places. And then get this, the top spot not technically a state but it's the nation's capital. According to the study, Washington, D.C. the best place for millennials to live.

Millennials make up 35 percent of D.C.'s workforce, key indicators of living standards like average monthly earnings for millennials and, of course, the unemployment rate for them were looked at. D.C. millennials say that the abundance of people their age is also a big attraction for moving there. So, staying with the younger generation, looks like young adults, the share of them that are living with their parents is right now at the highest in 75 years. This is depressing parents.

A few research center study found that 33 percent of 25 to 29-year-olds live with their parents or their grandparents in 2016, that's almost three times as many that live with their parents, Dagen, in 1970. I don't know about you, but when I was 18, I got out of high school my parents were like, "Bye, good luck. Take care."

MCDOWELL: Yes. My dad gave me $20 when I graduated from college and said, "Hey kiddo, I can't find you a job. If you get married, here's $20, elope, I don't want to know about it." Said, "That's a dowry."

CASONE: Same story, yes.

MCSHANE: Is that exactly what you did?

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: No -- yes, actually, about 10 years later. Thanks Collin for bringing up that happy memory. Think of -- what do you think of millennials living at home?

JAIN: Oh, rent is so expensive nowadays. I mean, this is the problem. Like you're spending 55, 60 percent of your income in New York on rent, it's no surprise people were staying at home.

MCDOWELL: You actually have backed a company that's trying to connect the -- that's trying to ease the down -- the -- not the down payment but the security deposit.

JAIN: Right. So actually, one of our biggest focuses right now at Kairos is building new technologies to help reduce the cost of rent. The one you're talking about is Rhino.

One of the problems of renting is not just the monthly recurring cost, just to move in to a place, you're spending $10,000 plus. Nobody has that kind of liquid cash coming out of college. So we basically created a company that waive security deposits for folks.

BELL: Yes. I just moved and it's been a pain in the butt with all upfront cost and then you have to buy furniture and different things like that, find a new gym and --

JAIN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I suspect you saw that list to the best places for millennials to live, Minnesota and North Dakota is because the cost of living is so low.

JAIN: Actually, I also got to find that list. I don't know who came up with that.

BELL: Well D.C., the technology corridor could be potential driver.

MCSHANE: That's true, it's not just politics.

BELL: Yes.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: If you're an entrepreneur encore, you can start a business anywhere, even in North Dakota.

JAIN: I agree with you. I mean, I just think -- I will be shocked if you surveyed a random poll of millennials and that that was the order of favorite cities.

MCSHANE: The good shell oil start-up in North Dakota.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. Again, the future. Coming up, all options on the table, that's the word from the White House as the president looks to show force against Syria.

And you'll be digging deeper this summer to drive and fill up your tank, gas prices spiking. We'll tell you why the real sticker shock may be from your gas station credit card bill.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The art of a trade war, U.S. trade officials and Chinese metal importers squaring off. According to the Wall Street Journal, U.S. trade officials are laying blame on Chinese firms for rerouting goods to other countries to get around tariffs.

And this coming after China said it would open market and ease some import tariffs particularly on auto imports. Futures are looking like this this morning, again, the selloff is picking up steam, it was a great day for stocks yesterday. We have a 181 point loss on the Dow Futures right now.

Joining me from the CME Group, the PRICE Futures Group and FOX News Contributor, Phil Flynn. What do you make of this latest development Phil?

PHIL FLYNN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think when we're looking at the difficulties of actually enforcing a potential trade war when it comes to transshipping. And if you look at the markets today, we're really trying to balance the reducing risk of a trade war versus a rising risk of a real war in Syria.

So you have a lot of dynamics to play with the markets, a lot of nervousness. But actually, I guess I have to say that President Donald Trump strong line with China appears to be bearing fruit. And overnight, of course, President Trump tweeted and basically thanked President Jinping from China for his kind words on the tariffs and talking about his problems with intellectual property. So it looks like President Trump's strong arm has -- bearing some fruit this morning.

MCSHANE: Yes, it's interesting Phil the President Xi's comments, how they worked into markets yesterday and then no doubt played a role especially in the stock market in the gains we saw and you're right, we got a talk coming up I think about Syria that maybe that hasn't affect on today's selloff that we're seeing.

But do you think President Xi knew exactly what he was doing there? In other words, this is going to be a long drawn out process, these negotiations and he -- I would bet that he knew by saying what he said that the markets would react as they react, maybe buys him a little bit of time too to negotiate.

FLYNN: I think he did. I think he wanted to lower the temperature a little bit. If you remember China started the week off really tough, putting sanctions on U.S. soybeans which was basically their nuclear options.

I think President Xi wanted to ratchet down the tensions and basically give up on what he knows is indefensible. I think everybody in the world realizes that the Chinese import tariffs on cars is way out of whack, the entire world knows that that's indefensible. The stealing of intellectual property, everybody's against that. Everybody knows that China is playing fast and loose with the rules.

So I think on the things that were indefensible, he's going to come out and try to adjust their position and I think it does open the doors for negotiations and there probably will be no trade war.

MCDOWELL: From your mouth Phil, thank you so much. Phil Flynn from CME Group, we'll see you soon.

Serious action for Syria, the president weighing a massive military strike and what that would mean for the United States and our relationship -- our tense relationship with Russia.

And forget Sci-Fi images of the surface of the moon, there's a new 4K view of the planet that you will not be able to take your eyes off of, that's ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern. Markets under pressure this morning, we have 179-point loss on the Dow Futures, a weaker open for stocks is on deck. Investors are waiting on inflation data and minutes from the last Federal Reserve meeting, coming out later today, maybe its concerns about Syria and a strike, an impending strike.

This, coming after a big rally yesterday, China said it would open up its economy and makes some concessions on the tensed trade relationship the U.S. has with China. Checking global market action in Europe, markets are edging lower. And in Asia overnight, it was mixed action, the two markets there that headed south, the Nikkei in Japan and KOSPI in South Korea. Targeting Syria, President Trump looking to rally support for a possible missile strike against Bashar al-Assad after the suspected chemical attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: We're going to continue to work with a number of our partners and allies as we determine what the next best steps are. I just saw the troops yesterday. I don't have anything new on that front in terms of things that the President may or may not do. We are not going to broadcast.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This, as the United States positions warships within firing range of Syria. Deadline day, the FBI and justice department have until today to turn over the unredacted memo that led to essentially spying on a U.S. citizen, Carter Page, that counterintelligence Russia investigation. The House Intelligence Committee Chairman, Devin Nunes, threatening legal action if law enforcement does not comply.

Bank of America, taking action on guns, it will stop lending the gun makers that produce so-called assault-style weapons for civilians. Peak driving season, kicking off in a few weeks, new numbers show you'll be paying more at the pump, more on that, plus, the fresh warning for drivers over gas station credit cards.

A night, 10 years in the making, one NBA player debuting with a performance, so good, it could not even have been scripted any better, we have the highlights, and a whole new way to see space, NASA unveiling a virtual tour of the moon.

But, first, the Trump administration rallying allies for a possible military strike on Syria, the prospects for U.S. action, rising yesterday, after Russia rejected a U.N. Security Council Resolution to investigate the alleged chemical weapon's attack. White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders weighed in yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: The President has been clear, we're working with our partners and allies and our National Security team to look at all options and as we've said, all options are on the table, but I'm not going to get ahead of anything the President may or may not do in response to what's taking place in Syria.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This coming as a European air traffic control agency is reportedly alerting airlines to exercise caution due to potential air strike in Syria in the next three days. Joining us now, is National Security Analyst for the Clarion Project, Professor of Counter-Terrorism at Liberty University, Ryan Mauro. Ryan, you were previously a volunteer researching for a Syria opposition group before the Civil War started. What is your take on this? What does the U.S. need to do here?

RYAN MAURO, PROFESSOR OF COUNTER-TERRORISM, LIBERTY UNIVERSITY: Well, the immediate objective is to have some type of deterrent effect on Assad, so that the chemical weapons attacks and other forms of attacks, like the barrel bombs, can be stopped.

And that's very doable because he has a weak air force, we have the capability to strike at his shipments of fuel, the stuff that's coming in and out of the ports that the Russians have to use, so there's plenty of targets that are vulnerable, hitting just a handful of them, would have a dramatic effect on the ground and has to be more than punishment.

What has to happen is that the dictator Assad has to actually look at the situation and say, my chances of losing this war go up when I do things like this, and therefore I'm going to stop doing it, and that's the calculation we have to aim for.

JAIN: Even if he has Russia on his side, preventing that?

BELL: Russia did say, they came out this morning. I saw a news report that said they would retaliate, they would look to stop any missiles coming to Syria and they would strike any places where those missiles were coming from.

MAURO: We've heard that every time there's been some type of confrontation with a Russian ally, that's, kind of, just how they talk. And if you look at what happened with the air strike last year, we gave a warning to the Russians. They got their people out so that there weren't casualties. There was an arrangement. And giving that heads-up, doesn't really make much of a difference if you're going after hard targets because you can't pick those up and that's really what you're going after.

MCSHANE: This is more aggressive than that (INAUDIBLE) what you're talking about is a step-up from what we did last year, so there has to be more risk involved, no?

MAURO: There is. MCDOWELL: Well, you mentioned the hearing with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau director, -- acting director, Mick Mulvaney. HENSARLING: Well, again, you well pointed out, you wonder what's been going on at Wells Fargo. I mean, clearly all kinds of problems. I mean, I know they have new management in place but it seems like every single day another shoe is dropping from something happening under the old management. And you wonder why didn't we create an entire new agency that supposedly had employees embedded in the job and they still didn't figure it out.

There's a couple different problems with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. It's -- remains the most unaccountable, most powerful Federal agency in the history of the Republic. That was true under Richard Cordray, an Obama appointee . It's true under Mulvaney, a Republican- appointee. They're just not accountable. There's no checks and balances. They take their money straight from the Fed. They're not on the appropriations process.

The President can only fire the head of the CFPB for cause. The courts and there's something called the Chevron deference have to basically put their thumb on the scale in favor of the CFPB. And then finally, there's not even a them at the CFPB, there's only a him, one person can basically wake up on the wrong side of the morning and outlaw any credit card, checking account or mortgage he wants to.

That is fundamentally in opposition to the American foundational value of checks and balances and frankly, a lot of people are being denied due process. They are Congress, prosecutor (INAUDIBLE) judge, jury, all rolled into one which our founders in the Federalist papers, I think it was Federalist 47, Madison, would have called the very definition of tyranny. So number one, they're unaccountable. Number two, they're hurting consumers.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HENSARLING: Free checking has been cut in half at banks. There are 15 percent fewer credit cards that cost 200 basis points more. It's much harder for middle income Americans to find mortgages. And so these are the problems we have to get to.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, Herman Cain has a question.

MCSHANE: That's a really good point.

CAIN: And I agree with you, 200 percent. Absolutely. It was remarkably unremarkable. Most of them knew that going in but it was the opportunity to get five minutes on T.V. That's all it was about. And nothing's going to come out of this, other than Zuckerberg is going to say, well, I'm highly concerned about this whole, you know, screening out conservative stuff. We will take that under advisement.

BELL: Yes, exactly. I think that's a great point, Herman. Scott, what does Mark do after two days of testimony in front of Congress?

GALLOWAY: He goes back to work and he does nothing, and he hires more lobbyists, there's a lot of job (INAUDIBLE) for lobbyists, for Facebook. The bigger -- the folks that are about to go gangster on Facebook right now are in Europe, specifically (INAUDIBLE). Europe in the last week has made more progress if you will or proposed more legislation against Facebook than America has to date. France is talking about taxing them on their top line because Google figured out a way to do $7 billion in revenue in the U.K. and paid $50,000 in taxes. They're talking about regulating Facebook and Twitter as media companies and Britain. Their GDRP is well ahead of anything we're doing. This is a nothing burger here in D.C.

MCSHANE: See, he was told specifically -- his notes, they didn't really leak, they were -- pictures were taken of his notes as they were left out on t he --

MCDOWELL: The A.P. -- right, A.P. took -- the A.P. photographer got a shot of the notes, the prep work that his lawyers had done for him.

MCSHANE: And to Scott's point, he was talking exactly what you were saying, he was instructed if that came up to not really say anything about it, to not come out and say -- which is interesting, well, what would your take would be on this, he was told apparently according to those notes, don't say we're already doing what they're regulating in Europe, that we're already doing that. Apparently, it said that in his notes that he wasn't supposed to come out and say that.

GALLOWAY: Well, there's been a lot of serious lies in big tech. Information wants to be free, that was a lie. We not only comply with the tax laws, we comply with the spirit of the tax laws. That was Tim Cook. The spirit of U.S. tax laws isn't that you issue your I.P. to the isle of man so you can suppress taxes in the U.S., high-tax domain, and increase them in low-tax domains. That's not the spirit of the U.S. tax law. The most recent big lie from big tech was Mark Zuckerberg saying, I'm not sure we shouldn't be regulated. I'd really like to know if the lobbyists in D.C. representing Facebook are running around saying, you know what, we're open to regulation. That is so ridiculous. They will fight tooth and nail any regulation.

CAIN: The only thing that Mark Zuckerberg said that I agree with, if Congress passes regulations, as you know they're going to be too big and too many and it's going to keep any challengers out of the marketplace because a new start-up is going to have a tough time dealing with it. I agree with you. Leave them alone. Let the customers of Facebook decide Facebook's future.

MCDOWELL: It was pretty clear based on the questioning that the last tech gadget some of these senators had bought was a Playskool View-Master, that they don't -- they have no concept of how even cell phones work quick frankly. You brought up taxes. I want to bring up this issue with you, Scott. 15 U.S. corporations including Amazon found ways to avoid taxes on nearly $25 billion in combined profits last year. This is a report from the institute on taxes and economic policy. Amazon received $137 million rebate on $5.4 billion in profits resulting in an effective tax rate of a negative 2-1/2 percent. And Trump -- of course, President Trump's been attacking Amazon for not paying enough in taxes. But again, this kind of goes to your point.

GALLOWAY: We've institutionalized a regressive corporate tax structure. Since 2008, Wal-Mart has paid $64 billion in corporate income tax, Amazon has paid 1.4 billion. This is despite the fact that Amazon has added a value of Wal-Mart to its Market cap in the last three months.

So what we've effectively we -- our tax system around big tech is sort of the Hunger Games. If you survive it and you win, you live a fabulous life and you can avoid taxes. The tax system is so complex and so favors large multinationals that it's basically a transfer of wealth from small domestic and medium-sized companies that only have domestic operations to large multinationals who can afford large tax departments and then can do these sort of -- these unnatural gymnastics to figure out a way to suppress their taxes in high-tax domains. We have -- Amazon is about to view us -- Amazon is about to become the most valuable company in history, and effectively pay no tax.

So, the question becomes when the most successful company in the world doesn't pay taxes, who does pay taxes? And it's simple, less successful companies pay taxes. You know, Alexa, is this a good thing?

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. I want to ask you, though, about with Facebook and its future. Do you think that the problem was -- you look at -- I was talking to a well-known investor yesterday and he said the government just stood back and did nothing because they have no understanding of technology and they don't want to, quote, get in the way of innovation. That Amazon - - that Facebook should never have been allowed to buy Instagram, for example, that they just let the company get bigger and bigger and bigger with no control.

GALLOWAY: Well, going back to Herman's comments, I don't think the revolution is going to be consumer-led. I think consumers are lazy and talk of big game about supply chain ethics and then want that little black dress for 9.99 and their espresso pods delivered within 48 hours for free. I don't think this is going to be consumer-led. And when 280 million Americans, 213 million of them are on Facebook, you don't really have any choice. In addition, when you have 5 million advertisers and no one advertiser can really hurt you, you're a monopsony. Advertisers have no choice but to be on Facebook. So, bottom line, this is a monopoly. I think the answer is to break these guys up, Facebook, Instagram, messenger, WhatsApp, healthier for the economy.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You can take your mic off. Drop it. Great for you. That was a drop-the-mic moment. Scott Galloway, thank you so much.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Merger talks between Sprint and T-Mobile, reportedly back on. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with more. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Dagen. So, yesterday, we saw Sprint soaring 17 percent, T-Mobile also jumping. So now, this is the third time in four years that these two companies are getting together. Last round of talks broke up at the end of November. They've now rekindled with the talks because they want to share the burden of investing and all the costs that they face. But now, it's who's going to have control. Because you have GermanDeutsche Telekom, they're seeking control. They obviously are the part of the T-Mobile. And then you have SoftBank Group that is -- has a majority stake for Sprint. So, this is what they're ironing out. But again, they're still in the early stages, so don't get too excited.

And the other story that is sort of the back story is that the cell tower stocks have been under pressure because they have concerns that they might have to cut their costs. Let's look at Spotify. Spotify's an exciting story, right? We had a direct listing, the reference price is 132. But now they're saying -- and they soared at the open and it's been doing great. Big product change, free music service that they're going to be pushing going forward. They have their 9.99, but Spotify is looking down about one percent today. And watch on April 24th, they may have a new speaker. They're going to have an announcement. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange. Markets under pressure this morning over rising tensions with Syria and of course Russia. In a pair of tweets earlier, President Trump threatened the Kremlin over its defense of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and said their relations with Russia are worse than ever. Joining me now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. Stuart, your thoughts?

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Well, actually, Dagen, I think the President was tweeting and saying very clearly, here come the missiles, watch out, boys, because they're on their way virtually. I think we can expect a strike. I mean, the President has teed this up quite obviously. We can expect a strike in the relatively near future. My question is how does the Market react? Granted, you're down 200 on Dow Futures at the moment as you run up to the in expected strike but what happens when the strike takes place? Does the market fall some more or does it recover?

I remember in times past when as soon as the missiles are fired off, the Market goes up. It goes down as you wait for the fire. And then it goes up when they've been fired. I wonder if the same thing will happen this time. I think a lot depends on the extent of the missile hit, whether Russian and/or Iranians get killed in the hit, and any possibility that they'll be followed up with more later? I think the market reaction depends on that. But I would not be surprised to see a move up when those missiles are launched.

MCDOWELL: This is President Trump using Twitter in the best way, to communicate very forcefully and directly.

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And people always wring their hands and nash about how Trump is on Twitter so much. But this, you can't get more direct and powerful than the statements he made just out.

VARNEY: It's immediate, isn't it? I mean, it's flat-out immediate. He comes -- he tweets, and you know full well that the Russians are waiting for the tweet. They're not waiting for a statement from the State Department, they're looking for the tweet. And reliably, here it is. By the way, I hope I'm not offending my friend there, Scott Galloway. I know what a socialist he is. I know how he obviously dislikes the whole idea of American military adventures overseas. I don't want to upset the guy in the middle of your show, OK? I just want that to be very clear.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: OK. I love you, Stuart. You're on in nine minutes. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: This breaking news right here, right now. House Speaker Paul Ryan will announce today that he will not run for re-election and he will retire at the end of the year. He plans to tell the GOP House members today that he will not seek re-election. Herman, your take on this.

CAIN: Well, it's a loss for the Republicans to lose that seat. But they might hold the seat but secondly, it means a change in leadership for the Republicans in the House. And to be honest with you, that may not be a bad thing. Because when Ryan was running for the speaker's position, there were a number of people vying for it. So, it's going to open up the competition for people who really want to be in that. And secondly, I happen to believe that Ryan may have just said I've had enough. You can't imagine the pressure that you are under to try to basically herd 245 cats uphill and that's just the Republican side, in order to get something done.

MCDOWELL: The thing about what happened just last year, in President Trump's first year in office, the House got an Obamacare fix passed, what would have been a giant fix of Medicaid. What did the Senate do with it? Gave it a thumbs down. Paul Ryan, clearly, when Maria interviewed him in mid-February, he was very clearly upset about that no-vote from Senator John McCain. Then they got the tax reform through, which I've been a naysayer among many, I didn't think they would be able to get it done, that he would be able to accomplish that. So, he has that huge win under his belt, time to hit the bricks.

CAIN: He is leaving with a grand slam homerun under his belt and that is the tax cuts and jobs plan, you're absolutely right. So, it's going to be will be a horse race.

MCSHANE: There's a number of conservatives though -- no secret -- that aren't big fans of Paul Ryan. That said, he did -- he did raise a lot of money for all the criticism that came in from him for the base. So,now you have a dynamic right in the midterm election where the speaker has already apparently going to announce that he's not running. That's your main fundraiser, too, that's kind of out of the game, and kind of the backdrop of everything else that's going on. You'll have a run for Republican leadership. I wonder how it affects the dynamic, I guess is the -- is the main question.

CAIN: It will be interesting. I think we'll have to wait and see. Because that is a major, major change with respect to the dynamics of politics for 2018.

MCDOWELL: And I do want to point out that there was a report out that -- of the Republicans who were expected to have dinner with President Trump tonight, House Speaker Paul Ryan being one of them, Kevin McCarthy, John Cornyn, and Mitch McConnell will be -- we'll see if the dinner plan is changed, but again, it -- I wonder if this actually helps bring enthusiasm at the base. Paul Ryan's not the most well-liked people --

CAIN: I would agree, 50 percent of the base was not that enthusiastic about his leadership. So, it could possibly bring some enthusiasm to the base.

MCDOWELL: I didn't -- think it's safe to say he wasn't as hated as John Boehner.

CAIN: Oh, no, no, no, no. Not in the least. But he got a big job done, the tax cuts and jobs plan.

MCSHANE: Do you think there's no marijuana company he wants to be on the board of? No, I don't think so.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's all over my head.

MCSHANE: Sorry.

MCDOWELL: Does Paul Ryan want to run for a higher office? We'll be right back, everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Thanks all, Herman Cain. Stuart Varney, take it away.

VARNEY: I shall. Good morning, Dagen, and good morning, everyone. The President orders the Harry S. Truman carrier battle group to the Mideast.

END
