Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S3B-X4Y1-JBHT-D36S-00000-00FB Led Technically as Mark Zuckerberg Testified Before Congress; WSJ: U.S. Points Finger at Chinese Firms for Transhipping; White House Weighs Actions in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack; Nunes Prepared To Impeach Head of FBI and Deputy Attorney General2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:06ZLexisNexisFB Led Technically as Mark Zuckerberg Testified Before Congress; WSJ: U.S. Points Finger at Chinese Firms for Transhipping; White House Weighs Actions in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack; Nunes Prepared To Impeach Head of FBI and Deputy Attorney GeneralLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning ladies, I'll see you both shortly. Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th. Your top stories at 6a.m. Eastern.

Stocks surging, the Dow climbing more than 400 points yesterday after China's President Xi Jinping promised an open market and to cut tariffs on auto imports. Futures are showing this, 400 plus point gain on the Dow Futures on the Dow yesterday. Ninety point loss on the Dow Futures today.

In Europe, stocks there mostly lower. Across the board losses in England, France, and Germany, although slight. And it was mixed reaction in Asia overnight with gains in Shanghai and on the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

One of the top winners yesterday, Facebook shares seeing their biggest gain in two years, up about four and a half percent as CEO Mark Zuckerberg did an admirable job facing a grilling on Capitol Hill from people who clearly didn't understand Facebook, some of them. He was grilled on everything, from the Cambridge Analytica scandal, Russian election interference, you name it, he was asked it, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility and that was a big mistake and it was my mistake and I'm sorry. I started Facebook, I run it, and I'm responsible for what happens here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: What Mark Zuckerberg's testimony could mean for future regulation in the tech sector, that's ahead. He's back on Capitol Hill at 10:00a.m. this morning.

Nunes fighting back, the Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee set to go after Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and FBI Director Christopher Wray as the Justice Department still refuses to provide him with an unredacted document showing the justification for their Russia probe. The latest on the tensions in the Capitol, that's ahead.

Bank of America changing its stance on firearms. The bank says it will no longer lend money to companies that make so-called assault rifles for civilians.

Plus, never give up on your dreams, after spending 10 years in the development league, on basketball player delivers a slam dunk in his long- awaited NBA debut. The incredible story coming up.

And one small step for man, one giant leap online, NASA helping you channel your inner Neil Armstrong with a brand new virtual tour of the moon.

All of that coming up and so much more this morning, CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. FOX Business's Connell McShane. And Kairos Founder, Ankur Jain. Ankur, just really quickly, what was your take on Zuckerberg yesterday?

ANKUR JAIN, FOUNDER, KAIROS: I'm going to tell you, Mark did a great job. I mean, all things considered.

MCDOWELL: I love how you refer to him by his first name.

JAIN: But I mean look, I got to tell you, the good thing was I think that Zuckerberg did a great job for Facebook. I think the challenge that the congressmen had no idea what to ask to actually address the problem, and that's a challenge. This is an important topic. And if you're going to have the Senate sitting there taking the time to figure out what regulations technology need, they need to know the right questions asked.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN ANCHOR: Yes, right. We have another episode of old people talking technology at 10:00 this morning, right? They had no idea how to follow-up was the main point.

JAIN: I mean, honestly some of other was just a lack of understanding what Facebook is. Somebody -- I forget which one of the congressman held up a poster board of five Facebook groups and goes, "Mr. Zuckerberg, are you -- can you authenticate that these were not owned by Russian trolls?"

If I were him, I would have been like, "There are three billion groups. I don't remember every single group." I mean, it's just --

MCSHANE: Right.

JAIN: It's just a shame.

MCDOWELL: He was prepped. He bought the kind of legal prep that billions of dollars can buy, put it that way. And he followed the script that was handed to him, we'll get into that. That's what we're talking about, the top of the show.

And coming up this morning, Texas Congressman, House Financial Services Committee Chairman, Jeb Hensarling. Texas Congressman Ted Poe. Former Presidential Candidate Herman Cain. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Dr. Mike, Dr. Mikhail Varshavski on the snake diet, yes, that's one of our things that we'll be discussing with Dr. Mike.

But to our top story this hour, Mark Zuckerberg squaring off with lawmakers on Capitol Hill, the Facebook CEO testifying for about five hours before skeptical senators who demanded answers on how the social media company allowed Cambridge Analytica to misuse the personal data up to 87 million Facebook users.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DUBIN (D), ILLINIOS, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE MEMBERS: Mr. Zuckerberg, would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?

ZUCKERBERG: No.

DUBIN: If you've messaged anybody this week, would you share with us the names of the people you've messaged?

ZUCKERBERG: Senator no, I would probably not choose to do that publicly here.

MCDOWELL: This is President Trump using Twitter in the best way, to communicate very forcefully and directly.

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And people always wring their hands and nash about how Trump is on Twitter so much. But this, you can't get more direct and powerful than the statements he made just out.

VARNEY: It's immediate, isn't it? I mean, it's flat-out immediate. He comes -- he tweets, and you know full well that the Russians are waiting for the tweet. They're not waiting for a statement from the State Department, they're looking for the tweet. And reliably, here it is. By the way, I hope I'm not offending my friend there, Scott Galloway. I know what a socialist he is. I know how he obviously dislikes the whole idea of American military adventures overseas. I don't want to upset the guy in the middle of your show, OK? I just want that to be very clear.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: OK. I love you, Stuart. You're on in nine minutes. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: This breaking news right here, right now. House Speaker Paul Ryan will announce today that he will not run for re-election and he will retire at the end of the year. He plans to tell the GOP House members today that he will not seek re-election. Herman, your take on this.

CAIN: Well, it's a loss for the Republicans to lose that seat. But they might hold the seat but secondly, it means a change in leadership for the Republicans in the House. And to be honest with you, that may not be a bad thing. Because when Ryan was running for the speaker's position, there were a number of people vying for it. So, it's going to open up the competition for people who really want to be in that. And secondly, I happen to believe that Ryan may have just said I've had enough. You can't imagine the pressure that you are under to try to basically herd 245 cats uphill and that's just the Republican side, in order to get something done.

MCDOWELL: The thing about what happened just last year, in President Trump's first year in office, the House got an Obamacare fix passed, what would have been a giant fix of Medicaid. What did the Senate do with it? Gave it a thumbs down. Paul Ryan, clearly, when Maria interviewed him in mid-February, he was very clearly upset about that no-vote from Senator John McCain. Then they got the tax reform through, which I've been a naysayer among many, I didn't think they would be able to get it done, that he would be able to accomplish that. So, he has that huge win under his belt, time to hit the bricks.

CAIN: He is leaving with a grand slam homerun under his belt and that is the tax cuts and jobs plan, you're absolutely right. So, it's going to be will be a horse race.

MCSHANE: There's a number of conservatives though -- no secret -- that aren't big fans of Paul Ryan. That said, he did -- he did raise a lot of money for all the criticism that came in from him for the base. So,now you have a dynamic right in the midterm election where the speaker has already apparently going to announce that he's not running. That's your main fundraiser, too, that's kind of out of the game, and kind of the backdrop of everything else that's going on. You'll have a run for Republican leadership. I wonder how it affects the dynamic, I guess is the -- is the main question.

CAIN: It will be interesting. I think we'll have to wait and see. Because that is a major, major change with respect to the dynamics of politics for 2018.

MCDOWELL: And I do want to point out that there was a report out that -- of the Republicans who were expected to have dinner with President Trump tonight, House Speaker Paul Ryan being one of them, Kevin McCarthy, John Cornyn, and Mitch McConnell will be -- we'll see if the dinner plan is changed, but again, it -- I wonder if this actually helps bring enthusiasm at the base. Paul Ryan's not the most well-liked people --

CAIN: I would agree, 50 percent of the base was not that enthusiastic about his leadership. So, it could possibly bring some enthusiasm to the base.

MCDOWELL: I didn't -- think it's safe to say he wasn't as hated as John Boehner.

CAIN: Oh, no, no, no, no. Not in the least. But he got a big job done, the tax cuts and jobs plan.

MCSHANE: Do you think there's no marijuana company he wants to be on the board of? No, I don't think so.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's all over my head.

MCSHANE: Sorry.

MCDOWELL: Does Paul Ryan want to run for a higher office? We'll be right back, everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Thanks all, Herman Cain. Stuart Varney, take it away.

VARNEY: I shall. Good morning, Dagen, and good morning, everyone. The President orders the Harry S. Truman carrier battle group to the Mideast.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60GF-6DB1-F15W-H03B-00000-00FBN "COAST TO COAST" INTERVIEW WITH BRENDAN CARR, COMMISSIONER, FCC2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:05ZLexisNexisFBN "COAST TO COAST" INTERVIEW WITH BRENDAN CARR, COMMISSIONER, FCC

July 30, 2020

NEWS PROGRAM

BRENDAN CARR, COMMISSIONER, FCC

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN ANCHOR: Brendan Carr is with us right now, the FCC commissioner.

Commissioner, thank you for taking the time.

Is there something to this line of attack some of these guys are getting that they're much more zealous going after conservative thought than, let's say, I don't know, Ayatollah thought?

BRENDAN CARR, COMMISSIONER, FCC: Yes, I think, you know, what we saw yesterday with that hearing in Israel (ph), a government official pretty blatantly said, look, you know, tweets calling for genocide are permissible, other tweets commenting on political situations in other countries aren't. If it weren't for double standards, I'm not sure Twitter would have much.

You know, when you look right now, it's not so much that they have sort of a COVID misinformation policy, which we saw this week when they took down tweets from Donald Trump Jr.

If you go on Twitter right now, you can see tweets up from Democratic Congressman Swalwell that says don't wear masks. You can go on Twitter right now, today, and see tweets from the WHO that says there's no real evidence of human-to-human transmission of COVID.

So it's less about a misinformation policy, it appears, than an orange man bad policy. And it's playing fast and loose in arbitrary ways. And so I think some of the concerns you heard at that hearing yesterday are pretty well founded.

CAVUTO: I'm wondering what the solution is, though. A lot of people say, all right, if you're going to check conservatives on things that they're saying, you should check liberals on things that they're saying. Others say it's the Wild West, anyone can say whatever they want and, you know, reader, viewer beware.

What do you think?

CARR: Yes, if you go back to the hearing yesterday, I think what was interesting there was bipartisan consensus, which is rare in this town, as you know --

CAVUTO: Right.

CARR: -- that a lot of these big tech companies are abusing dominant positions in the market. Not just participating in the free market, but taking advantage of a level of a playing field that has been skewed by government regulation, including section 230.

The interesting debate is, what do you do about it. I think the Democrats have their path forward. They want to break up big tech. They want to block mergers and they want to see less speech on the Internet.

What's interesting is, I think on the Republican side, and for conservatives, which is really a -- a -- part of a broader debate about what we do. There's some that say we should just sit on our hands and do absolutely nothing in the face of this abuse of massive power.

I think that we should do more than nothing. I've laid out a path forward where we can work towards transparency, accountability, and user empowerment that will make a lot of progress on these issues.

CAVUTO: Do you worry, though, Commissioner, because then Democrats have their own beefs, as you know, with a lot of these guys, that they do very little -- did very little to explain and report on foreign election interference in our country, on -- that they're doing it all over again. That's a lot of things these guys supposedly have to do to police themselves.

Should they do that? In other words, whether it's offensive on the left or the right, that these are great public forums, whatever you make of them, and that the government getting involved in policing them will only make matters worse.

CARR: Yes, I don't think that the government should step in, and we shouldn't step in at the FCC, and micro-manage these decisions. What we have is Congress passed this law, as you know, Section 230 in the 1990s. That gave a special set of protections to what's now big tech and all other websites.

CAVUTO: Right.

CARR: And the question is, how do we interpret that law today? Can we do it in a way that promotes more speech, not less speech?

Again, I don't want to be micro-managing these decisions. We shouldn't be trying to skew the speech right or left. But like every business in this country, there should be some transparency and accountability.

If you say voluntarily we are a neutral platform politically, for all the take-downs that we do, we don't do partisan political take-downs. And then if, in fact, you're doing that, you should be held accountable.

In fact, we do that with broadband Internet providers today. We make them be transparent about anything they do to mold traffic or discriminate against traffic. That should be the baseline at a minimum for big tech. Let's make them be transparent and hold them accountable to their representations.

CAVUTO: FCC Commissioner Brendan Carr, thank you very much. Very good chatting with you.

CARR: Thanks.

END

urn:contentItem:5X16-KVV1-JBHT-D0WY-00000-00FBN "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" INTERVIEW WITH REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA) AND GOV. KIM REYNOLDS (R-IA)2019-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:06ZLexisNexisFBN "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" INTERVIEW WITH REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA) AND GOV. KIM REYNOLDS (R-IA)LanhamFULL TEXT

FBN "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" INTERVIEW WITH REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA) AND GOV. KIM REYNOLDS (R-IA)

SEPTEMBER 6, 2019

SPEAKERS: REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA) AND GOV. KIM REYNOLDS (R-IA)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR

[*] BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is California Congressman Ro Khanna, along with Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds. It is good to have you both with us. Thank you so much for being here. And Congressman Khanna, let me kick it off with you, tell me what you want to do here, in terms of rural jobs, across the country, created by tech?

REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA): Well, I've been very pleased to partner with Governor Reynolds and the local stakeholders in Jefferson, Iowa. We have had a number of Silicon Valley companies offer scholarships with Des Moines Community College, and offer a pathway for folks to get trained in digital marketing, in software design and be able to get jobs.

And they are going to be able to stay in the communities they grew up in. I really believe that Jefferson, Iowa can be a model for the country, in showing how we can create a technology opportunity in rural America.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you know, it's interesting because you've got technology taking us forward, certainly, making our live better in so many ways, but there's also that worry about privacy, right, Congressman? I mean, just today, we're talking all about facial recognition, for example, and you know, there are some colleagues on -- of yours, that are worried about things like ring.

The company that has that doorbell that you can see, you know, the camera. Amazon owns the doorbell camera company. It's facing questions from Senator Edward Markey, over its partnerships with police departments around the country and tracking citizens.

KHANNA: Well, Maria, there's no doubt that technology can be abused. I have put forward an internet bill of rights to be able to protect people's privacy and to make sure that technology isn't misused in engaging in profiling or discrimination.

But I think the challenge of our time is to maximize the positives of technology to allow people access to jobs that are going to have a technical component while minimizing the harm.

BARTIROMO: Governor, where do you sit on this? Tell us the situation in Iowa and how technology companies could create opportunities there?

GOV. KIM REYNOLDS (R-IA): Well, I'm really excited about the forge in this dynamic project and the opportunities that it provides for Iowans, especially in rural Iowa. I appreciate Congressman Ro Khanna and his involvement in really helping bring jobs to rural America. I want to give a shout out to Accenture for going beyond our urban centers and taking this model into rural Iowa.

We have a diverse in growing economy. We have one of the lowest unemployment rates in the country. And so, this is an opportunity not only to make sure that we are seeing that the success that Iowa is seeing, is happening all across our state and not just in pockets. And I believe with this model, it's an example that we can scale in rural communities all across Iowa and this country.

BARTIROMO: So, we have been talking all morning about the jobs report, we're going to get the numbers in 25 minutes, but one issue is that people need to be retrained, right? There's a real skills gap going on over there, throughout the country.

REYNOLDS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So, what do you want to say to people out there who, you know, maybe it's a -- you know, a construction worker, a truck driver, whatever, they don't know anything about coding. They don't know anything about some of this technology new, you know, million-dollar words that we're talking about. How are they going to thrive?

REYNOLDS: Well, we want to make sure we start and have that pipeline in middle school and high school so that we are training our young people to be adaptive, to be lifelong learners, but we have a program in Iowa that we launched a couple years ago, and that we're really -- it's -- we're implementing it right now and it's called Future ReadyIowa.

And it has a goal of having 70 percent of Iowans, in the workforce, have either education or training beyond high school by the year 2025. We've put funding into that so that we can help not only with the pipeline for our K-12, but to work with our adult learners to provide that support system, to help them get the skills, to match them up with the jobs that we have available in the state right now.

These are great careers to help them be lifelong learners and the -- I believe, the hub, like the forge, is an opportunity to -- you know, to serve as a launchpad, to retrain, to help kids get the skills to fill the jobs, so --

BARTIROMO: I think it's an important point.

REYNOLDS: -- we're seeing this happen all over the state. Pardon?

BARTIROMO: So, I think it's an important point that you make about older workers, because, that's the group, white collar too, by the way, who are being left behind in some -- in some regard. Congressman Khanna, let me ask you about these antitrust investigations, the Texas attorney general set to lead an effort, looking into Google and digital advertising, this, according to "The Wall Street Journal."

New York attorney general is also overseeing a review of Facebook and personal data concerns. These investigations could expand to other companies. What do you want to see in terms of regulation, on big tech, knowing that these companies are more powerful today than they've ever been?

KHANNA: Well, I think we, obviously, have to enforce antitrust law and make sure that these platforms are competitive, that they aren't privileging their own products, but we also need to make sure that we are innovative. America leads the world in innovation. Our technology is far superior to any tech company in Europe. And our real competition is China.

And so, I want to make sure that we have strong antitrust enforcement, but I also want to make sure that America leads the world in technology. And a quick point, I think you're absolutely right, Maria, that there are going to be jobs in all different industries, manufacturing, construction, logistics --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

KHANNA: -- not everyone has to go become a coder, but everyone is going to need some technology skill --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KHANNA: -- even in the industry that they may work in.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's absolutely right. The skills training is really important at this moment in time. Does it bother you that Google has an A.I. lab in China? I mean, look, this China fight with the U.S., is getting deeper. Retail giant, Target, is telling suppliers ahead of the September 1st tariff hike, they'd have to pay for additional costs, not consumers. Beijing is (ph) also feeling the tariff pinch, a report from the Tokyo investment bank, Nomura, says that countries like Vietnam and South Korea are benefiting the most from the trade impasse.

And we know, Governor, that Google walked away from a contract with the Pentagon, Project Maven, and yet, it has an A.I. lab in China. Is there any reason to believe that China will try to dictate or meddle in the U.S. elections through Google?

REYNOLDS: Is that to me?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

REYNOLDS: Oh, I'm sorry. OK. Well, listen, I think that's something that we need to be mindful of. We know that China has been a bad actor. We need to hold them accountable, and that's what we're trying to do. And so, it's important that we take this seriously, and that we, you know, stay firm in what we're trying to do through the negotiations of -- with China, but they have a history of being a bad actor.

They -- it's intellectual property and technology transfer is a cost of doing business. Our businesses are aware of that. And so, we need to hold them accountable.

BARTIROMO: I'm just -- I'm just wondering about Google, Congressman Khanna, because, you know, you heard Peter Thiel's comments, right? I mean, Peter Thiel wrote an op-ed and he said it's a national security risk, that Google has an A.I. lab in China, what do you think about that? Any worries?

KHANNA: Well, I agree with Governor Reynolds that China has been stealing intellectual property. There's no doubt about that. We need to protect our most sensitive technology from going to China. I don't think we ought to allow China, access, to our most sensitive technology.

What we also need to do, as a country, is invest in the technologies of the future, Artificial Intelligence, quantum computing --

BARTIROMO: Are we doing enough of that?

KHANNA: -- and make sure America leads --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KHANNA: -- in the industries of the future.

BARTIROMO: You're right, especially as China wants to be number one in all of those industries, so you wonder if we are, in fact, doing enough. It's great to have this conversation with you both, and it's great to see you both working together on this very important project. Thank you, Congressman Ro Khanna and Governor Kim Reynolds, good to see you both.

REYNOLDS: Thank you.

KHANNA: Thank you.

END
